content.text: Directions for the following 4 (Four) items : Read the following two passages and answer the items that follow the passages. Your answer to these items should be based on the passages only.

Passage -1 It is hard to predict how changes in the climate and the atmosphere's chemistry will affect the prevalence and virulence of agricultural diseases. But there is a risk that such changes will make some plant infections more common in all climatic zones, perhaps catastrophically so. Part of the problem is that centuries of selective breeding have refined the genomes of most high-value crops. They are spectacular at growing in today's conditions but genetic variations that are not immediately useful to them have been bred out. This is good for yields but bad for coping with changes. A minor disease or even an unknown one could suddenly rampage through a genetically honed crop.

questions.question_text: Which one of the following statements best reflects the central idea conveyed by the passage?

content.text: (a) Global climate change adversely affects the productivity of crops. (b) Our total dependence on genetically honed crops entails possible food insecurity. (c) Our food security should not depend on agricultural productivity alone. (d) Genetically honed crops should be replaced with their wild varieties in our present cultivation practices.

questions.question_text: With reference to the above passage, the following assumptions have been made : I. Global climate change can result in the migration of several plant diseases to new areas. II. Scientific understanding of the wild relatives of our present crops would enable us to strengthen food security. Which of the above assumptions is/are valid?
questions.explanation: Assumption I is valid: The passage mentions that "there is a risk that such changes (in climate and atmosphere's chemistry) will make some plant infections more common in all climatic zones." This suggests that climate change may lead to the spread or migration of plant diseases to areas where they were not prevalent before. Hence, this assumption is valid. Assumption II is valid: The passage highlights the vulnerability of genetically honed crops due to the loss of genetic variation. While it doesn't directly mention wild relatives, the implication is clear that reintroducing genetic diversity (often found in wild relatives) could help crops cope with new or changing threats. Therefore, scientific understanding of wild relatives would contribute to strengthening food security. Hence, this assumption is also valid.

content.text: “A good statesman, like any other sensible. human being, learns more from his opponents than from his fervent supporters. For his supporters will push him to disaster unless his opponents show him where the dangers are. So if he is wise he will often pray to be delivered from his friends, because they will ruin him. But, though it hurts, he ought also to pray never to be left without opponents; for they keep him on the path of reason and good sense. The national unity of free people depends upon a sufficiently even balance of political power to make it impracticable for the administration to be arbitrary and for opposition to be revolutionary and irreconcilable.”

questions.question_text: Which one of the following statements best reflects the critical message conveyed by the author of the passage?
options: Without opposition parties, the administration in a democracy gets to become more responsible.
Democracy needs to have revolutionaries in opposition to keep the government alert.
Rulers in a democracy need the support of opposition for their political survival.
In a democracy, the opposition is indispensable for the balance of political power and good governance.
questions.explanation: Option (a) is incorrect: This option claims that “without opposition parties, the administration in a democracy gets to become more responsible,” which contradicts the message in the passage. The author says, “he ought also to pray never to be left without opponents; for they keep him on the path of reason and good sense.” This implies that opposition keeps the administration responsible, not the lack of it. Hence, this option is not correct. Option (b) is incorrect: The passage does not support the idea that “democracy needs to have revolutionaries in opposition.” On the contrary, it stresses the importance of a “sufficiently even balance of political power” so that opposition is not “revolutionary and irreconcilable.” Therefore, the author does not advocate for revolutionaries in opposition. Hence, this option is not correct. Option (c) is incorrect: While the passage emphasises the value of opposition in guiding rulers, it does not say that rulers need opposition for “political survival.” It says they need opponents to remain reasonable and avoid being ruined by blind supporters: “he will often pray to be delivered from his friends… he ought also to pray never to be left without opponents.” So, the focus is on wisdom and good governance, not political survival. Hence, this option is not correct. Option (d) is correct: This best reflects the main message of the passage. The author clearly states that opponents help keep a leader “on the path of reason and good sense” and that “the national unity of free people depends upon a sufficiently even balance of political power.” These lines show that opposition is essential for maintaining a healthy democracy and ensuring responsible governance. Hence, this option is correct.

questions.question_text: With reference to the above passage, the following assumptions have been made : I. In a democracy, a strong opposition is required only if the Head of Government is indifferent. II. The more aggressive the opposition, the better is the governance in a democracy. Which of the above assumptions is/are valid?
questions.explanation: Assumption I is incorrect: The passage never suggests that a strong opposition is needed only if the Head of Government is indifferent. Instead, it says, “he ought also to pray never to be left without opponents; for they keep him on the path of reason and good sense.” This shows that opposition is always necessary in a democracy to ensure balance and prevent arbitrary decisions — not just when a leader is indifferent. Assumption II is incorrect: The passage values a balanced and reasonable opposition, not an aggressive one. It warns against an “opposition to be revolutionary and irreconcilable,” suggesting that overly aggressive opposition may harm democracy. Therefore, the idea that more aggressive opposition leads to better governance is not supported.

questions.question_text: P is the brother of Q and R. S is R's mother. T is P's father. How many of the following statements are definitely true? I. S and T are a couple. II. Q is T's son. III. T is Q's father. IV. S is P's mother. V. R is T's daughter. VI. P is S's son. Select the correct answer using the code given below:
questions.explanation: Here, we will denote the relations using the following signs:

content.text: According to the given pieces of information in the question, we can draw the following family tree: So, statements I, III, IV and VI are definitely correct, i.e. four statements.

questions.question_text: If NO is coded as 210, NOT is coded as 4200 and NOTE is coded as 21000, then how is NOTES coded?
questions.explanation: NO = 14 (place value of N in alphabet series) × 15 (place value of O in alphabet series) = 210; NOT = 14 × 15 × 20 = 4200; NOTE = 14 × 15 × 20 × 5 = 21000; NOTES = 14 × 15 × 20 × 5 × 19 = 399000. Note: There’s another pattern being followed: NO = 210 (i.e. 21 followed by 1 zero); NOT = 4200 (i.e. 21×2 followed by 2 zeroes); NOTE = 21000 (i.e. 21 followed by 3 zeroes); NOTES = 420000 (i.e. 21×2 followed by 4 zeroes). So, technically option (b) can also be rendered correct. However, logic behind choosing option (a) is stronger in comparison, as it makes use of the actual letters of the words, not just that of the number of letters in the words.

questions.question_text: If FRANCE is coded as 654321 and GERMANY is coded as 9158437, then how is YEMEN coded?
questions.explanation: Here, each digit corresponds to a particular letter. F R A N C E , G E R M A N Y , Y E M E N 6 5 4 3 2 1, 9 1 5 8 4 3 7, 7 1 8 1 3.

questions.question_text: The 5-digit number PQRST (all distinct digits) is such that T is not equal to 0. P is thrice T. S is greater than Q by 4, while Q is greater than R by 3. How many such 5-digit numbers are possible?
questions.explanation: P = 3T and T ≠ 0. Also, S - Q = 4, and Q – R = 3. So, S – R = 7. Also, R < Q < S. If T = 1, P = 3: PQRST = 3QRS1 Possible numbers are: 35291. If T = 2, P = 6: PQRST = 6QRS2 Possible numbers are: 64182, 63072. If T = 3, P = 9: PQRST = 9QRS3 Possible numbers are: 94183. Thus, there are four such 5-digit numbers. (We cannot take T = 4 or more, as then P will become a 2-digit number.)

questions.question_text: X can complete one-third of a certain work in 6 days, Y can complete one-third of the same work in 8 days and Z can complete three-fourth of the same work in 12 days. All of them work together for n days and then X and Z quit and Y alone finishes the remaining work in 8 4 * days. What is n equal to?
questions.explanation: X can complete one-third of a certain work in 6 days. So, X can complete total work in 6 × 3 = 18 days. Y can complete one-third of a certain work in 8 days. So, Y can complete total work in 8 × 3 = 24 days. Z can complete three-fourth of a certain work in 12 days. So, Z can complete total work in (4/3) × 12 = 16 days. Let the total amount of work be the LCM of 16, 18 and 24, i.e. 144 units. So, efficiency of X = (144/18) = 8 units/day. Efficiency of Y = (144/24) = 6 units/day. Efficiency of Z = (144/16) = 9 units/day. Efficiency of X, Y and Z together = (8 + 6 + 9) units/day = 23 units/day. Work done by Y in 26/3 days = (26/3) x 6 = 52 units. Remaining work = 144 - 52 = 92 units. Time required to complete this work when they work together = 92/23 = 4 days. So, n = 4.

questions.question_text: What is X in the sequence 1, 3, 6, 11, 18, X, 42?
questions.explanation: When we subtract consecutive terms of the given sequence, we get consecutive prime numbers. Hence, X = 29.

content.text: Over the next 30 years, many countries are promising to move to net-zero carbon, implying that household emissions will have to be cut to close to nothing. A leading climate scientist reckons that, at best, half the reduction might be achieved through demand-side measures, such as behavioural changes by individuals and households. And even that would require companies and governments to provide more incentives to change through supply-side investments to make low-carbon options cheaper and more widely available.

questions.question_text: Which one of the following statements best reflects the central idea conveyed by the passage?
options: (a) Moving to net-zero carbon is possible only by the reduction in household emissions.
(b) Low-carbon behaviour in people can be brought about by incentivising them.
(c) Cheaper goods and services can be made available to people by using low-carbon technologies.
(d) Manufacturing industries that use low-carbon technologies should be provided with subsidies.
questions.explanation: Option (a) is incorrect: This option claims that 'moving to net-zero carbon is possible only by the reduction in household emissions,' but the passage states that 'at best, half the reduction might be achieved through demand-side measures,' which includes household behavior. This shows that household emissions alone are not sufficient to achieve net-zero, so this option is incorrect. Option (b) is correct: This option states that 'low-carbon behaviour in people can be brought about by incentivising them,' which matches the passage's point that achieving even half the required emission reduction 'would require companies and governments to provide more incentives to change.' Thus, this reflects the central idea of the passage accurately. Option (c) is incorrect: This option shifts the focus to the affordability of goods and services, saying 'cheaper goods and services can be made available,' but the passage mentions making 'low-carbon options cheaper' as a way to support behavior change, not as a central idea. Therefore, this is a secondary detail, not the main message. Option (d) is incorrect: This option talks about giving subsidies to manufacturing industries, but the passage makes no mention of subsidies or specific focus on industries. The emphasis is on incentivizing low-carbon choices for individuals and households through supply-side support. Hence, this option introduces an idea not supported by the passage.

questions.question_text: With reference to the above passage, the following assumptions have been made: I. Supply-side investments in companies can result in low-carbon behaviour in people. II. People are not capable of adapting low-carbon behaviour without the involvement of Government and Companies. Which of the above assumptions is/are valid?
questions.explanation: Assumption I is correct: The passage clearly states that achieving household emission reductions 'would require companies and governments to provide more incentives to change through supply-side investments to make low-carbon options cheaper and more widely available.' This implies that supply-side investments can influence people’s behaviour toward adopting low-carbon practices. Hence, assumption I is valid. Assumption II is incorrect: While the passage mentions that incentives from companies and governments would be required for significant behavioural change, it does not say that people are completely incapable of adapting on their own. The phrase 'at best, half the reduction might be achieved through demand-side measures' suggests that some change can occur independently.

content.text: be achieved through demand-side measures” implies that some behavioural change is possible without external involvement, although less effective. Therefore, assumption II overstates the dependency and is not fully supported by the passage.

In only 50 years, the world's consumption of raw materials has nearly quadrupled, to more than 100 billion tons. Less than 9% of this is reused. Batteries of old vehicles contain materials such as lithium, cobalt, manganese and nickel that are pricey and can be hard to obtain. Supply chains are long and complicated. Buyers' risks are being aggravated by their suppliers' poor environmental and labour standards. Reusing materials makes sense. Once batteries reach the ends of their lives, they should go back to a factory where their ingredients can be recovered and put into new batteries.

questions.question_text: Which one of the following statements best reflects the most logical, rational and pragmatic message conveyed by the passage?
options: (a) Green economy is not possible without reusing critical minerals.
(b) Every sector of economy should adapt the reuse of material resources immediately.
(c) Circular economy can be beneficial for sustainable growth.
(d) Circular use of material resources is the only option for some industries for their survival.
questions.explanation: Option (a) is incorrect: This option states, “Green economy is not possible without reusing critical minerals.” While the passage highlights the importance of reusing critical minerals like lithium, cobalt, manganese, and nickel found in vehicle batteries, it does not make the absolute claim that a green economy is impossible without them. The message is more about promoting reuse as a rational and beneficial approach, not asserting it as the only way to achieve a green economy. Therefore, this option overstates the case and is not the most accurate reflection of the passage. Option (b) is incorrect: This option claims, “Every sector of the economy should adopt the reuse of material resources immediately.” The passage focuses specifically on materials in used vehicle batteries and does not generalise to all sectors of the economy. There is no suggestion in the passage that all sectors must act immediately. Hence, this statement extends beyond what the passage supports and is too broad and prescriptive. Option (c) is correct: This option states, “Circular economy can be beneficial for sustainable growth.” This accurately captures the central message of the passage. The passage discusses how less than 9% of materials are reused and suggests that materials from old batteries should be recovered and reused: “Once batteries reach the ends of their lives, they should go back to a factory where their ingredients can be recovered and put into new batteries.” This embodies the principles of a circular economy, where materials are continuously reused, promoting sustainability. Hence, this option best reflects the logical, rational, and pragmatic message of the passage. Option (d) is incorrect: This option states, “Circular use of material resources is the only option for some industries for their survival.” While the passage suggests that reuse is a wise and beneficial strategy due to price and supply risks, it does not go so far as to say it is the only option for the survival of any industry. Therefore, this is an exaggeration of the message and not supported by the text.

questions.question_text: With reference to the above passage, the following assumptions have been made : I. Automobile factories are examples of the circular economy. II. Economic growth is compatible with circular use of mineral resources. Which of the above assumptions is/are valid?
questions.explanation: Assumption I is incorrect: The passage suggests that batteries from old vehicles should be reused by recovering materials to create new batteries. This indicates that current practices are not circular. Therefore, assumption I is not valid. *However, there is a possibility that Assumption I could be taken as correct: The passage highlights that batteries from old vehicles contain valuable materials like lithium, cobalt, and nickel, which should be recovered and reused in new batteries. It states that once batteries reach the end of their life, “they should go back to a factory where their ingredients can be recovered and put into new batteries.” The passage, therefore, discusses the possibility of the automobile sector becoming circular, where resources are reused instead of being discarded, and hence can be taken as an example. Assumption II is correct: The passage discusses the extensive use of raw materials and the very low percentage of raw materials re-used, and argues that reusing materials makes sense and that recovering valuable minerals from old batteries helps alleviate supply and environmental risks. This implies that sustainable and efficient reuse (a principle of circular economy) can support continued economic activity and growth. Therefore, this assumption is valid and logically drawn from the passage.

questions.question_text: A set (X) of 20 pipes can fill 70% of a tank in 14 minutes. Another set (Y) of 10 pipes fills 3/8th of the tank in 6 minutes. A third set (Z) of 16 pipes can empty half of the tank in 20 minutes. If half of the pipes of set X are closed and only half of the pipes of set Y are open, and all pipes of the set (Z) are open, then how long will it take to fill 50% of the tank?
questions.explanation: 20 X pipes can fill 70% tank in 14 minutes. So, 20 X pipes can fill 100% tank in (14/70) × 100 = 20 minutes. 10 Y pipes can fill 3/8th of the tank in 6 minutes. So, 10 Y pipes can fill 100% tank in [6/(3/8)] × 100 = 16 minutes. 16 Z pipes can empty 50% tank in 20 minutes. So, 16 Z pipes can empty 100% tank in 40 minutes. As per the question, X and Y work at half their capacity, while Z work at full capacity. So, Set X pipes can fill the tank in 40 minutes. Set Y pipes can fill the tank in 32 minutes. And, Set Z pipes can empty the tank in 40 minutes. We can see that pipes X and Z will eliminate each other’s efforts. So, the question boils down to this: In how much time will Y fill 50% of the tank? As Y can fill the entire tank in 32 minutes, it will fill half the tank in 16 minutes.

questions.question_text: If n is a natural number, then what is the number of distinct remainders of (15 + 25) when divided by 4?
questions.explanation: 1n is always 1. When we divide 1 by 4, we always get 1 as the remainder. 2n when divided by 4, can give either 0 or 2 as remainder. (We will get 2 as the remainder only when n = 1) Hence, when we divide (1n + 2n) by 4, we can get either (1 + 0) or (1 + 2), i.e. 1 or 3 as remainder. So, two distinct remainders are possible.

questions.question_text: Let P = QQQ be a 3-digit number. What is the HCF of P and 481?
questions.explanation: P = QQQ = Q × 111 = Q × 3 × 37  (Q can be 1, 2, 3, ……, 9) And, 481 = 13 × 37 So, HCF of P & 481 = 37  (as Q cannot be 13)

questions.question_text: What is the 489th digit in the number 123456789101112...?
questions.explanation: First 9 digits: 1, 2, 3, ….. , 9 Next 180 digits = 10 to 99 So, remaining digits = 489 – 189 = 300, which all will be formed using 3-digit numbers. So, the number of 3-digit numbers to be used = 300/3 = 100

content.text: Hence, the next 100 numbers forming the subsequent 300 digits must be: 100, 101, 102, …., 199. It’s evident that the last digit is 9.

questions.question_text: A mobile phone has been stolen. There are 3 suspects P, Q and R. They were questioned knowing that only one of them is guilty. Their responses are as follows: P: I did not steal. Q stole it. Q: R did not steal. I did not steal. R: I did not steal. I do not know who did it. Who stole the mobile phone?
questions.explanation: One of them is guilty, and hence must be lying. We need to see the logical consistency of the three statements even when one of them is lying. Case I: P is lying, while Q and R are telling the truth. It means that, P stole the mobile phone. Now, we need to check whether statements made by Q and R are also consistent or not. If P was the thief, then it’s obvious R and Q did not steal. So, statement made by Q seems valid. If P was the thief, then it’s obvious R did not steal. So, statement made by R seems valid too. This case seems to be the correct one. Hence, P stole the mobile phone. But let’s quickly go through the other two possible cases. Case II: Q is lying, while P and R are telling the truth. As per P, Q was the thief. However, as Q is lying, there are two thieves (both Q and R). This is logically inconsistent. Case III: R is lying, while P and Q are telling the truth. As per P, Q was the thief. However, as R is lying, R must be the thief. This is logically inconsistent. Note: Here, we are assuming that when a person lies, both his statements are a lie. In case, these people are lying partially (one statement is a true, while the other is false), then the answer would be option (d). For example, in Case II mentioned above, if in Q’s statement, “R did not steal.” is true, and “I did not steal.” is false, then it means that Q was the thief.

questions.question_text: Three teams P, Q, R participated in a tournament in which the teams play with one another exactly once. A win fetches a team 2 points and a draw 1 point. A team gets no point for a loss. Each team scored exactly one goal in the tournament. The team P got 3 points, Q got 2 points and R got 1 point. Which of the following statements is/are correct? I. The result of the match between P and Q is a draw with the score 0 -0. II. The number of goals scored by R against Q is 1. Which of the statements given above is/are correct?
questions.explanation: Teams play each other exactly once, so there are 3 matches in total. P vs Q, P vs R, Q vs R. Team P (3 points): P must have won 1 match and drawn 1 match. Team Q (2 points): Q must have drawn both the matches. Team R (1 point): R must have lost 1 match and drawn 1 match. As P has won one match and R has lost one match, it’s obvious that P must have defeated R. As a team must score at least one goal to win, P must have scored its lone goal in this match. So, scoreline of P-R match would have been 1-0. Now, P cannot have scored any other goal in the tournament. Which means that scoreline of P-Q match would have been 0-0. So, the scoreline of Q-R match would have been 1-1. So, both statements are correct. Hence, option (c) is the correct answer.
